slides.text:
HYALINE:
articular surface covered in a thin layer of cartilage

JOINT CAVITY filled with synovial fluid:
provides lubrication and nutrition to the cartilage

SYNOVIAL MEMBRANE:
Sleeve of delicate cartilage attached around the periphery of the articular surface - contains SYNOVIAL FLUID

FIBROUS CAPSULE:
Externally strengthens the synovial membrane

pages.title: Diagram to show a typical synovial joint

slides.text:
OSTEOCHONDROSIS:
young animal e.g. Great Dane and Newfoundland

Insensitive - no nerve supply and is avascular - disease can progress a long way before there are clinical signs

CARTILAGE-HYALINE: 
-Translucent glossy surface 
-White tinge with blue in young 
-Yellows with age
-Shock absorbing 
-Smooth surface

pages.title: High powered diagram of the articular surface

slides.text: e.g. TEMPOROMANDIBULAR JOINT (Much bigger in herbivores)

pages.title: Diagram to show articular discs and menisci (meniscus)

slides.text:
Discs and menisci - hyaline and fibrocartilage
FUNCTION:
-Provide congruence (eg femur is curved and tabia is not therefore incongruent) for incompatible joint surfaces.
-Resolve complex movements into simpler components
-Provide some shock absorption

E.g. proximal interphalangeal joint
-Movement is flexion and extension

COLLATERAL LIGAMENTS:
powerful, strong (medial and lateral) restrict the movement of flexion and extension

E.g. femorotibial joint of the stifle

COMMON AXIS:
movement is unilateral about an axis common to the two condyles

E.g. radiocarpal joint
-Movement in two planes
